title: PE Daily: Thoma Bravo Sells Partial Stake in Command Alkon | Peak Rock Maps Out Deal for Survey Company
text:
Dive in for more details ...

Today's Top Stories

Software-focused private-equity firm Thoma Bravo is selling a 45% stake in Command Alkon Inc., a provider of supply-chain-management software for the heavy construction industry, to HeidelbergCement AG in a deal that values the company at about $1.7 billion, Preeti Singh reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity, citing people familiar with the matter. Thoma Bravo will keep a majority stake in the Birmingham, Ala.-based company, which it acquired last year.

Private-equity firm Peak Rock Capital has acquired SAM Cos., betting it can help the mapping-and-survey company accelerate growth and expand geographically. SAM provides services like land surveying and construction inspection to utility, transportation and other infrastructure developers. Peak Rock's SAM deal valued the business at hundreds of millions of dollars, according to a person familiar with the matter who declined to provide more details.

Big Number

$120 Billion

The value of U.S. leveraged buyout loans issued during the first nine months of this year, the most for a full year since the financial crisis and near the record of $123 billion set in 2007, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence data.

Deals

Vista Equity Partners is offering to take private automation software maker Blue Prism Group PLC for 1,125 pence per share, or about $15.41 per share, valuing the U.K. company's equity at the equivalent of about $1.5 billion. The offer represents a roughly 35% premium to the closing price of the shares on Aug. 27, the day before Blue Prism said the offer period began, according to a regulatory filing. Blue Prism said its directors intend to recommend the bid to shareholders. The company also said that owners of about 23% of the company's shares have indicated they would accept the deal. Vista plans to combine Blue Prism with its Tibco Software Inc. portfolio company, according to the filing.

Francisco Partners is investing in business data provider SourceScrub LLC, investing alongside existing backer Mainsail Partners and company founders and managers, according to an emailed news release. The growth investment is expected to fuel expansion of the San Francisco-based company, which gives clients in private equity, venture capital, investment banking and corporate development access to information on roughly 1.7 million companies.

Warburg Pincus has invested $130 million in Conexiom, a provider of software and technology that helps manufacturers and distributors automate their sales order and invoices. The firm joins Conexiom's existing investors Luminate Capital, which acquired the company in 2018 and remains a majority shareholder, and ICONIQ Growth, according to a press release.

Alvarez & Marsal Capital, a private investment firm that has a strategic association with advisory firm Alvarez & Marsal, has acquired pet supplies company Worldwise Inc. largely through the firm's flagship midmarket private-equity strategy A&M Capital Partners. Novato, Calif.-based Worldwise was majority owned by fellow private-equity firm Mistral Equity Partners.

General Atlantic led an investment of more than $60 million in healthcare company Stellar Health LLC, with existing investors Point72 Ventures and Primary Venture Partners participating in the Series B round. The New York-based company works with insurers, government programs, doctors and hospitals to help improve healthcare outcomes, according to its website.

Marlin Equity Partners is making a majority investment in risk and cybersecurity management software provider ProcessUnity Inc., which has been backed by private-equity firm Long Ridge Equity Partners, the company's majority shareholder since 2018, according to a press release. Long Ridge will retain a minority stake in the Concord, Mass.-based company.

OceanSound Partners has invested in infrastructure inspection and certification company RMA Group. The Rancho Cucamonga, Calif.-based company provides technology-enabled services to ensure that the construction, operation and maintenance of critical infrastructure remains in compliance with regulatory and safety requirements.

Growth investor TA Associates said it has agreed to back Caprock, a privately held multi-family office that advises on more than $7.5 billion in client assets. Caprock has deployed more than $1.5 billion in impact-oriented capital across all asset classes, according to a news release.

Essex Bay Capital, a private-equity firm focused on small and midmarket buyouts, has made a growth investment in Munetrix LLC, a technology company that provides municipal and school district data management tools and analytic applications, according to a press release.

Fort Port Capital has invested in CellSite Solutions LLC, a Cedar Rapids, Iowa-based provider of asset management and refurbishment services for telecom infrastructure, according to a press release issued by Skyway Capital Markets which advised CellSite on the deal.

Dallas-based Paceline Equity Partners said it has bought two hotels in the Charlotte, N.C., area: the Holiday Inn Express & Suites Charlotte Ballantyne and the TownePlace Suites Charlotte Fort Mill.

Atlantic Street Capital is backing radiological services provider Prestige Medical Imaging LLC. The Newburgh, N.Y.-based company provides equipment services and maintenance for hospitals, clinics and physician practices across the eastern U.S.

Exits

Goldman Sachs Group Inc.'s Petershill Partners PLC shares fell at the opening in their first day of trading in London after the fund-of-funds investment specialist priced the offering at 350 pence per share, or about $4.74, giving it a market capitalization of about £4 billion, equivalent to $5.41 billion, and raising about ​​£1.2 billion. The firm offered about 29% of its equity in the IPO. After falling to near 340 pence at the opening, the shares recovered to close at the offer price of 350 pence. Petershill backs fund managers, venture capital firms and hedge fund operators. London-based Petershill holds stakes in private-equity firms like Accel-KKR, Francisco Partners and Riverstone Holdings, for example.

Olaplex, a beauty company that was acquired by Advent International in early 2020, has raised the target price range for its initial public offering, a move that could value the company at as much as $12.3 billion, Luisa Beltran writes for sister publication Barron's.

Funds

New Water Capital, a lower midmarket private-equity firm co-founded by former professionals from Sun Capital Partners, is seeking $400 million for New Water Capital Partners II LP and a related parallel fund, according to a regulatory filing. New Water raised $406 million for its debut fund back in 2015, ahead of a $250 million target.

Golding Capital Partners said it aims to raise €300 million, the equivalent of $350.9 million, for its first impact-focused fund of funds. The Munich-based asset manager expects to back around 15 funds with a smaller allocation for co-investments, according to a press release.

Vensana Capital, a firm focused on growth and venture investments in medical technology companies, said it has raised $325 million for its second fund to back companies across sub-sectors that include medical devices, diagnostics and data science, life science tools, digital health, and tech-enabled services. The firm was launched in 2019 by Justin Klein, a former partner at New Enterprise Associates, and Kirk Nielsen, a former managing director from Versant Ventures.

People

The Vistria Group, a Chicago-based midmarket private-equity firm, announced several senior hires and is opening a new office in Dallas. The firm said it has hired Boris Rapoport, a former managing director from Lightyear Capital, as a partner and co-head of financial services at the firm, and that Mona Sutphen, who has been a senior advisor at the firm, will become a partner and head of investment strategies. Finally, the firm has tapped Bill Macatee as a partner and head of strategic relationships in its newly opened Dallas office, where he will lead operations. Mr. Macatee has also served as a senior advisor at Vistria.

Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe is hiring Dr. Paul Taheri as a clinical partner in the healthcare-focused private-equity firm's Resources Group, according to a news release. Most recently he was the chief executive of Yale Medicine and deputy dean for clinical affairs at the Yale School of Medicine.

Healthcare-focused private equity firm Frazier Healthcare Partners said Amanda Bosse has joined the firm's growth buyout team as an executive in residence to focus on outsourced pharmaceutical contract manufacturing and scientific services. Ms. Bosse has more than 20 years of experience in the pharmaceutical industry and most recently served as president of drug product services for Thermo Fisher Scientific, a press release indicated.

Graycliff Partners has added Pradeep Saha as an operating partner to help evaluate deal opportunities and work with portfolio company managers on strategy and expansion initiatives. He is currently chairman of portfolio company Worldwide Electric Corp. in Rochester, N.Y.

Industry News

More than 130 federal judges have violated U.S. law and judicial ethics by overseeing court cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock, James V. Grimaldi, Coulter Jones and Joe Palazzolo report for the Wall Street Journal. A Journal investigation found that judges have improperly failed to disqualify themselves from 685 court cases around the nation since 2010. The jurists were appointed by nearly every president from Lyndon Johnson to Donald Trump.

Canadian pension investment manager Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec plans to exit investments in oil production by the end of next year as part of its strategy to reach a net-zero carbon strategy, which includes holding a certain level of "green assets" in its portfolio by 2025 and by reducing the portfolio's "carbon-intensity" by 60% by 2030. CDPQ said oil production assets account for about 1% of its portfolio.

Multi-strategy investment firm P10 Inc., which backs smaller midsized businesses with its RCP Advisors private-equity funds, has filed for an initial public offering of shares, without specifying an amount or price range for the IPO. The Dallas-based firm also makes venture capital, private credit and direct impact investments and had about $14.2 billion in fee-paying assets under management at the end of June, according to the filing. It had 76 professional employees spread across 10 offices in nine states at the end of June.

Asset manager Cresset Asset Management LLC and multi-family office Berman Capital Advisors said they plan to merge in a deal that would create a $20 billion multi-family office. The deal will significantly expand Cresset's team in the Atlanta region as all 33 of Berman's team members are joining Cresset, according to a press release.

Midmarket lender Monroe Capital said it has closed a $505 million collateralized loan obligation called Monroe Capital MML CLO XII, LTD, the firm's seventh CLO since March 2018.
